Running a Ripple server is comparable to running an email server in terms of electricity.

It might be a little surprising because I don’t think anybody was expecting this so soon, but a diverse group of participants has ALWAYS been part of the plan! I think this is why RippleNet exists. They (banks) agree to a set of standards that don’t burden outsiders.
Of course. Ripple can’t control what other people do with XRP.

It’s good for Ripple too. They’re a private company and who they choose to hire and give board seats to shouldn’t matter to outsiders who have no stake in the company. Separation was desperately needed!

When Ripple is the only one building on the network, it’s hard to separate support for the network and XRP from the company. This is the best thing that could’ve happened -another company with a stake in the network and zero ties or allegiance to Ripple.

Well, then we're already in crypto 4.0 :) There have been at least three major crashes/weedouts in late 2011, mid 2013, and 2014-2015 respectively in BTC alone. Ethereum has also had at least 3 crashes (pre-launch due to BTC crash, late 2015 drop, and mid 2016 after the DAO).

Ah, but people are already highly liquid! For example, BTC's trading volume over the last 24 hours was $6.8B while FB's was $2.5B. That's not a one-time thing either; crypto is already as liquid as the largest public tech stocks. http://www.nasdaq.com/symbol/fb https://coinmarketcap.com/
